content: A few points: 1. Candidates should be considered purely based on qualifications. Gender, race, religion, and other such things should not even be considered. If only women are being considered, then that is indeed sexism against men. 2. The SCOTUS is currently more representative of the "white male" demographic than any others. That does not mean we should not consider qualified white males... but it might indicate past unfairness in the selection process. You can not "fix" this with "reverse discrimination" (I hate that term), but moving forwards, it would be good to consider a diverse pool of candidates as a starting point each time a new appointee is considered. 3. FollowMeInfantry, you're usually correct on many things, but you got one of your facts wrong. You said: quote: Why is it against the law for me to refuse to hire a lesbian but within the law for him to hire one because of it? That's actually false. It is NOT against federal laws to refuse to hire a lesbian (or a gay man) based solely on sexual orientation. Some states have laws against it, but the majority of states do not. Essentially, in most of the United States, is it perfectly LEGAL to intentionally discriminate on the basis of sexual orientation. I wonder what would happen if a gay CEO were to intentionally discriminate against a straight potential employee? Just a theoretical situation, of course, but I do wonder.
